thread.title: Results from Reunion island Boeing 777 wing part to be announced today?
thread.title_full: Results from Reunion island Boeing 777 wing part to be announced today?

title: Results from Reunion island Boeing 777 wing part to be announced today?
text:
Save 
Experts examining the plane part found washed up on the island of Reunion last week, could announce their findings today, officials have said. 
The piece which understood to have come from a Boeing 777, has been taken to Toulouse in south-west France. 
An Australian transport expert is aiding the examination, at the invitation of the French authorities, with Malaysian experts also attending, the BBC reported, as well as Boeing employees and representatives from China – the country that lost the most passengers in the disaster. 
It is hoped they may reveal the origin of the wing part either today or later this week, according to officials. 
If it is that of the missing MH370 flight, investigators are hoping to establish what speed the aircraft was travelling at to use this information to then advise search teams to look for a plane which is either largely intact, or one that has disintegrated on impact. 
It is understood that the examination of the wing part will begin early on Wednesday afternoon, the AFP news agency reported. 
Jean-Paul Troadec, the former head of the French BEA agency that investigates air accidents, was quoted by AFP as stating that the examination would concentrate on two issues - whether the wing part belongs to MH370 and if so, whether it can provide any information on the final moments of the plane. 
Troadec added that paint on the wing part - which has already been confirmed as coming from a Boeing 777 plane - was a vital part of the investigation. 
“Every airline paints their planes in a certain way… and if the paint used is used by Malaysia Airlines and other companies, there may be more certainty,” he said. 
At the same time he also cautioned that the analysis was highly unlikely to offer any clues as to why the plane went off course. “One should not expect miracles,” he said. 
The Australian-led search for the missing MH370 was previously focused on a huge area of the southern Indian Ocean, some 4,000km (2,500 miles) east of Reunion.
